awd_titl_txt: SDI-CSCS: EP3: A Clean-Slate Software-Defined Approach for Enabling Elastic Security
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores a clean-slate approach to securing critical services in emerging Software-Defined computing and networking systems Infrastructure (SDI). The project explores a new, elastic and flexible security approach as part of a proposed Elastic Placement, Posture and Performance (EP3) framework. In EP3, elasticity applies to the amount of processing available to perform security tasks, as well as to the types of policy and the placement where the processing occurs. The proposed research addresses flexible security infrastructure in three ways. First, a research thrust will design a data plane with greater verifiability and confidentiality associated with in-network computation tasks. This gives network administrators greater flexibility in moving security critical processing to anywhere in the network. A second research task will be to develop a control plane that leverages placement flexibility to dynamically launch defenses as needed. Finally, the project team will develop a set of novel SDI-inspired security capabilities that highlight the benefits of elasticity in placement, posture and performance.

This research activity will develop and disseminate a set of open-source tools, modeling abstractions, algorithm designs, and prototype implementations that will dramatically reduce the time to deploy their techniques in current and future SDI deployments. The project team will also make the research results useful as an educational resource for students, and plan to integrate the outputs of the interdisciplinary research in key course projects in multiple classes spanning security, networking, and systems. The project will actively encourage research participation from underrepresented groups, and work closely with leading industry collaborators to evaluate the proposed techniques and deploy the solutions in operational settings.

por.por_cntn:
Security was only an afterthought in the initial design of modern network and computing systems. Since then, there have been significant commercial efforts and many research projects dedicated to securing our computing environment.

However, this post hoc approach has forced the community to carefully consider where and how to intervene on existing computations and communications to improve security, rather than considering how to embed security in the core design of the infrastructure itself. While clever designs at the perimeter of domains and at the endpoints have secured our computation infrastructure against many past threats, this approach has led to a rigid design that is increasingly showing weakness under more complex usage scenarios and more sophisticated attacks. Specifically, there are three broad ways in which today's security is rigid and inflexible:

  1. Placement: Today’s security approaches are limited in where they can operate in the networked environment. For example, many deployments secure the perimeter by using firewalls to filter traffic. Limiting placement limits the observations and actions that a security system can perform.
  2. Posture: The set of policies enforced by today’s security infrastructure tend to be relatively static. This makes it difficult to adapt security settings based on early observations of anomalous behavior or to accommodate applications such as IoT where access control lists (ACLs) may change based on the locations of users and their devices.
  3. Performance: The limited resources and lack of context at the edge of the network make it difficult for perimeter security techniques to defend a domain against attacks that exhaust these resources.

To address the security needs of the future, this project designed the Elastic Placement, Posture, and Performance (EP3) framework. In EP3, elasticity does not just apply to the amount of processing available to perform security tasks, but also to the types of policy and the placement where the processing occurs. EP3 leverages developments in "Software-defined infrastructure" (SDI) that offer a promising starting point for the design. 

EP3’s design attacks the problem of a flexible security infrastructure on three fronts. First, the PIs advanced data-plane designs by making them easier to program. Their work on systems such as TEA, Redplane, and Exoplane make it possible to write data-plane programs that degrade gracefully as resource needs exceed single-device constraints. Similarly, efforts such Pigasus made significant improvements in the performance of programmable data planes. Second, the EP3 control plane leverages important contributions in sketch-based network monitoring on programmable networks (Nitrosketch, SketchLib and HeteroSketch) and in verifiable, secure computation (Komodo, AuditBox). Finally, the PIs have demonstrated the potential gains from using the EP3 approach in a number of applications, including Adaptive  DDos Defence (Jaqen and Zeus) and high-speed intrusion detection (Pigasus). The Zeus system, in particular, was a proof-of-concept capstone implementation that built on artifacts and insights from various constituent pieces of EP3  as an integrative novel defense against future DDoS attacks.

The project has had a significant broader impact through the training of 2 Postdoctoral, 17 PhD, 3 MS, 8 undergraduate, and 2 high school students. This includes 12 women and 3 underrepresented minority students. Multiple components of the system have been released as open-source software. Finally, the results of the research have been disseminated in 23 publications at top-tier venues.  The publications are freely available on the PIs’ websites.
